titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Mirjan R. Damaška Papers on Yugoslavia, Serbia, and Montenegro
Damaska (Mirjan R.) Papers on Yugoslavia, Serbia, and Montenegro
titlestmt.author: compiled by Carol King

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday December 8, 2018 at 11:25

did.unittitle: Mirjan R. Damaška papers on Yugoslavia, Serbia, and Montenegro

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

langmaterial.language: The material is in English and Croatian.

did.abstract: The papers comprise correspondence, printed material, and a report compiled by Mirjan Damaška and other lawyers to suggest improvements in a draft treaty prepared by the Croatian government to convert the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia into a Confederation. Correspondence and printed material pertaining to the role of mediation to prevent war in the breakup of Yugoslavia and an appeal to end the war in Croatia are included.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Mirjan R. Damaška received his LL.B. at the University of Zagreb, Croatia, and his Dr. Jur. at the University of Ljubljana, Slovenia, in 1960. He began his teaching career at the University of Zagreb Law School. In 1971, he left Croatia to accept a position at the University of Pennsylvania Law School. Damaška joined the Yale Law School faculty in 1976 and is Sterling Professor Emeritus of Law and Professorial Lecturer in Law. He has served as advisor to the Croatian government in its relations with the International War Crimes Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia, and the International Court of Justice in The Hague since 1995.
Biographical information found on Yale Law School website.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to Yale University for unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Mirjan R. Damaška Papers on Yugoslavia, Serbia, and Montenegro (MS 1950). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The material is arranged as received from the donor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers comprise correspondence, printed material, and a report compiled by Mirjan Damaška and other lawyers to suggest improvements in a draft treaty prepared by the Croatian government to convert the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia into a Confederation. Correspondence and printed material pertaining to the role of mediation to prevent war in the breakup of Yugoslavia and an appeal to end the war in Croatia are included.

did.unittitle: Alliance of Yugoslav States, draft treaty and commentary

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The draft treaty, entitled "Treaty of the Alliance of Yugoslav States (or) The Alliance of South Eastern European States (Proposal)" was prepared by the Croatian government which sought advice on improvements in the draft from the Yale Law School.

did.unittitle: Correspondence regarding articles to prevent war in the breakup of Yugoslavia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence with President Jimmy Carter's Atlanta Center on Mediation.

did.unittitle: Correspondence regarding an open letter, "An Appeal for Peace in Croatia," New York Times
Croatia v. the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes bound writings by Damaška and others compiled by the American Croatian Society regarding United States recognition of Croatia.
